componenttext:
Thanks John, and we appreciate each of you for taking the time to be with us this morning.
Today, we announced strong quarterly results with reported earnings of $0.69 per share in the second quarter. After adjusting for restructuring and transaction costs, comparable earnings per share were $0.79. These comparable results include a negative currency impact of approximately $0.03 per share for the quarter. On a currency neutral basis, second quarter revenues increased 1% and comparable operating income was up over 20%.
Our second quarter results were achieved through volume growth and margin expansion in both Europe and North America. In Europe, we achieved volume growth of 5.5% with modest pricing per case growth and a one-half percent decline in cost of goods sold per case. Pricing per case growth was impacted by promotional mix, including World Cup as well as prior year hurdles. Cost of goods per case benefitted from modest commodity declines.
North America had modest volume growth and continued to achieve solid margin improvement benefitting from a 3% cost of goods sold per case decline. Though pricing overall had a modest decline, sparkling pricing was up despite negative mix. We also continued to benefit from effectiveness initiatives that enabled us to achieve lower operating expenses, and from ownership cost management, which is driving important bottom line savings.
These results, coupled with our positive first quarter performance as well as our outlook for the remainder of the year have enabled us to increase our full year guidance with comparable earnings per share now expected in a range of $1.73 to $1.77 including an expected negative currency impact of approximately $0.06 per share for the full year at recent rates.
Looking at the full year outlook for our business units, on a comparable and currency neutral basis, we expect Europe to achieve high single-digit operating income growth with a mid single-digit increase in revenue. In North America we expect a mid single-digit increase in operating income, and a flat to low single-digit decline in revenue. We have also increased our 2010 expected free cash flow to approximately $900 million. Our outlook for capital expenditures remains at approximately $1 billion.
We continued to expect interest rates to decline for the year and our expected tax rate to be approximately 26%. This guidance is based on CCE’s current business structure. One note consistent with our first quarter earnings call, we do not plan to provide specific guidance for either Norway or Sweden though we do understand these markets are broadly on track to achieve their respective full year financial objectives.
Overall, we are encouraged by our positive results for the first six months, but we must continue to execute the remainder of the summer selling season and maintain our focus on the strategies that have allowed us to limit cost and excel in the marketplace as we face challenging economic conditions in both Europe and North America.
Now, as John discussed, we have made good progress towards the finalizing the transaction with the Coca-Cola Company and remain on track to close in the fourth quarter. We have received positive notification from the European Commission, we are still awaiting a ruling from the internal revenue service. We are still waiting United States and Canadian antitrust approval, and of course, ultimately the deal must be approved by shareowners. However, we are optimistic that these steps will occur on a timely basis in keeping with our goal of a fourth quarter close. Also of importance, we have made good progress in preparing for the integration of the Norway and Sweden businesses.
Turning to our capital structure, we continue to expect net debt at close to be in a range of $2 billion to $2.5 billion, though this could fluctuate based on currency, cash from operations, and other factors. Also we expect to have financing in place for new CCE by the end of the third quarter. After closing, new CCE expects to return cash to shareowners via a planned share repurchase program of approximately $1 billion over the following 18 months and establish an initial annual dividend of $0.50 per share. This is in addition to a one-time $10 per share cash distribution that will be paid to shareownes at closing.
So, to summarize, we are pleased with our progress in the first half and the success of our marketplace strategies and operating initiatives. This reflects the excellent efforts and dedication of our employees who have continued to focus on delivering strong results while we work to transform our business to the transaction with the Coca-Cola Company.
Again, thanks for joining us today and now John, Steve, Hubert and I will be happy to take your questions.

Yes, thanks Caroline. First of all, from the portfolio standpoint, POWERade has had a terrific first half of the year. Our POWERade business is up 15%. On the strength of POWERade Zero, which continues to gain momentum but also base POWERade business is also up low single-digits. So, we are very, very pleased about the POWERade performance, and the momentum around POWERade.
From a water perspective, our single-serve water business was also up nicely in the first half of the year which is again a turnaround from the long-term trends, and our case pack water, we have been much more deliberate about how we promote case pack water, we are not chasing the very deep discount in case pack water, so the volume that we are losing there is non value-added volume, and we are very - I would not say we are very happy with that but it is a deliberate strategy and one that is working for us.
So overall - and vitaminwater, the launch of Vitaminwater Zero has been very successful and we returned that brand to growth so we are very pleased about that. So, overall, our still portfolio, which has been like everybody else affected by the recession over the last couple of years has now got renewed momentum across all the brands and categories. So, we are very pleased with that.
In terms of our overall execution, right execution daily has now been rolled out nationally, and it is a very successful program. It allows us to look at store-by-store changes over time, and setting objectives on a store-by-store basis, and when you look at our cases on display, we were up last year from cases on display perspective, and we are lapping that successfully this year. So our cases on display continue to grow. Our outlet level segmentation and our outlet level execution is going from strength to strength. So we acknowledge that we have a long way to go and we like to be humble about our performance, but we are pleased that we are making significant progress, and we have got momentum and we feel it is making a real difference in our business.
In terms of the boost zones, as I mentioned earlier, we are going to have over 100 boost zones by the end of the year. It is a program that is working for us. When we measure our boost zone performance on a store-by-store basis versus the control group, it is up substantially. So, it represents big investment for us but it is an investment that is paying off in better retail execution, better consumer satisfaction, better customer satisfaction, and a volume lift that is very pleasing for us.

Thank you, and good morning, everybody. We appreciate you joining us this morning on the first quarterly conference call for the new Coca-Cola Enterprises. Today, we’ll discuss our third quarter 2010 results and our outlook for the remainder of 2010.
Before we begin, I’d like to remind you all of our cautionary statements. This call will contain forward-looking management comments and other statements reflecting our outlook for future periods. These comments should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary language contained in this morning’s earnings release, as well as the detailed cautionary statement found in our most recent Proxy Statement and subsequent SEC filings and 10-Ks. A copy of this information is available on our Web site at www.cokecce.com.
This morning’s prepared remarks will be made by John Brock, our CEO; Bill Douglas, our CFO. Hubert Patricot, President of our European Group is also with us on the call this morning.
Following prepared remarks, we will open the call for your questions. In order to give as many people as possible the opportunity to ask questions, please limit yourself to one question and we’ll take follow-up questions as time permits.
Now, I’ll turn the call over to John Brock.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Thor, and we welcome each of you to the first quarterly conference call for our new Coca-Cola Enterprises. We’ve had an excellent start over the past three weeks. We’ve made progress in increasing value for each of our stakeholders, which i
componenttext:
Thank you, Thor, and we welcome each of you to the first quarterly conference call for our new Coca-Cola Enterprises. We’ve had an excellent start over the past three weeks. We’ve made progress in increasing value for each of our stakeholders, which includes of course, shareowners, customers, consumers, and employees.
We have a tremendous opportunity ahead of us at new CCE. Our European territories represent a vibrant marketplace for our beverage brands and products, and our team of employees and managers have the experience, skill and dedication needed to seize the many opportunities that lie ahead.
For more than four years, we have consistently grown and improved our business. We have confidence in our ability to continue moving this business forward as a new company. This confidence is enhanced by our solid results for the first three quarters of the year.
As we worked to close our transaction with the Coca-Cola company, we maintained focus on the need to deliver strong 2010 results in all territories, which of course is Europe as well as North America. The results we’ve announced today demonstrate that we are clearly on track to deliver a strong 2010.
Before I start our discussion of new CCE’s results, I’d like to express our appreciation to the Coca-Cola Company for their collaboration in working to close the transaction over the past several months. This was really a coordinated effort and is an excellent example of the type of positive relationship we have. We look forward to continuing to work closely with the Coca-Cola Company to drive sustained growth in Europe.
Now let’s take a look at the results for the third quarter, which as previously announced do not include North America, or our newly acquired territories in Norway and Sweden. For the quarter, we achieved very positive results through solid volume growth, modest pricing, controlled cost, and a stable commodity environment.
Revenue grew 4.5% with operating income growth of 7.5%. These results were driven by solid volume growth of 5%, which was balanced across all of our territories. Net revenue per case was up 1% and cost of goods sold per case was flat both on a comparable and currency neutral basis.
These results were driven by a combination of sparkling and still beverage volume growth. Sparkling drinks were up 3.5% on the performance of core Coca-Cola trademark, as well as solid growth in sparkling flavors, including energy.
For example, Coca-Cola trademark brands increased 3%, which is driven by Coca-Cola and Coca-Cola Zero, which in fact was up more than 15% versus last year. In flavors, energy grew more than 20% as we continued to expand distribution of Monster brands. In stills, wider distribution of Capri Sun, and the introduction of Ocean Spray helped to drive growth of some 15%.
In Great Britain, volume grew 3.5%, which is an improvement from the second quarter as we continue to manage through the impact of soft economic conditions. This growth reflects increases in sparkling flavors, energy, and still beverages. Dr. Pepper achieved growth of more than 15%, while the energy category was up more than 30%.
Volume for our Coca-Cola trademark portfolio was up 1% and we have strong plans underway to accelerate growth in this segment, with activation around our Christmas marketing programs and increased display space.
Continental Europe volume increased 6%, with excellent results both sparkling and still beverages. Brand Coca-Cola grew 2.5%, while Coke Zero was up more than 20%. Still beverages grew more than 20% through brand expansion and increased distribution.
Importantly our ability to seize future brand opportunities and to drive continued growth relies on our success in achieving even higher levels of service for our customers and in turn providing outstanding marketplace execution. We are working on ways to improve service through fresh looks at our routes to market.
We’re also enhancing segmented outlet execution that is tailored store-by-store to specific customer and consumer needs and better matching products and displays with local demand.
In addition, we continue to have an unwavering focus on managing cost. Ownership cost management remains an essential part of our day-to-day operations and a real priority across all CCE functions.
Now let’s briefly examine our outlook for the remainder of 2010. For legacy Europe today, we have confirmed our operating guidance from early September of high single-digit to low double-digit operating income growth, with mid single-digit revenue growth. We also expect Norway and Sweden to perform in line with expectations. This will translate in pro forma comparable earnings per diluted common share in a range of $1.74 to $1.78, which does include results from Norway and Sweden, and excludes non-recurring items.
Bill will provide a bit more color on our financial outlook in a few minutes. For just a moment I want to turn now to North America, which was a part of legacy CCE throughout the third quarter until the close of the transaction.
North America had a really outstanding quarter with volume growth of 2.5%, net revenue per case up 1%, and operating income growth of more than 20%. This represents a solid step forward for North America and demonstrates the skill and dedication of our employees and our management team.
This group delivered outstanding results amid continuing challenging economic conditions. I am very proud of the North American group and proud of the hard work and professionalism that they bring to the marketplace every day. They will be a tremendous asset to the Coca-Cola Company and we wish them the very best in the years ahead.
I also want to thank two former members of our CCE executive team for their leadership and support. John Downs, our Senior Vice President of Public Affairs and Communications has been with CCE since its earliest days. He has provided great counsel and direction, and we offer him our very best as he begins his new role at the Coca-Cola Company.
We are very pleased that Steve Cahillane is President of Coca-Cola Refreshments. Steve’s tremendous insight and leadership skills will be invaluable in building on the recent improvement in North American operating results.
While we will miss both John and Steve, we’re certain that the Coca-Cola Company and the entire Coca-Cola system will benefit from their knowledge and their experience.
Now going forward, a key step is to complete the integration of the Norway and Sweden territories. We are on track with excellent teams in place in both territories and we appreciate their hard work and their commitment. As we build our new CCE, our vision remains to be the best beverage sales and customer service company.
To accomplish this, we will continue to rely on our three key strategic priorities. Grow the value of our existing brands and expand our product portfolio, and be number one or number two in every category where we choose to compete.
Secondly, to continually transform the way we go to market and improve efficiency and effectiveness, so that we will be our customers most valued supplier. And third, to create a winning inclusive culture that attracts, develops and retains a highly talented and diverse workforce.
Today, CCE is a dramatically different company than we were a few months ago with an improved growth outlook yet these priorities remain essential to our success as the ultimate goal remains the same to drive consistent sustainable growth and ultimately create a superior investment return for our shareowners.
Throughout our company, there is a growing sense of pride and enthusiasm for achieving our objectives and our goals. We have great opportunities before us and the people of Coca-Cola Enterprises are prepared to create the value we expect and that our shareowners and customers deserve.
Thank you for joining us today, and now I’ll turn it over to Bill to go into more detail on our financials.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and we appreciate each of you taking the time to be with us this morning. I’m very pleased to discuss third quarter results for new CCE. As John mentioned, this is our first quarterly report and follows the close of the transaction with

Thank you, John, and we appreciate each of you taking the time to be with us this morning. I’m very pleased to discuss third quarter results for new CCE. As John mentioned, this is our first quarterly report and follows the close of the transaction with the Coca-Cola Company on October, the 2.
Before I turn to the results, it is worth noting that just eight months ago, we announced this transaction with the target of a fourth quarter close. We reached that goal and in fact closed on the first day of the fourth quarter and I’m extremely proud of everyone who was involved in the process.
Many members of our team at CCE as well as colleagues from the Coca-Cola Company devoted significant time and effort to make this happen. While many, many others focused on delivering our 2010 operating results, and important to note both were critical to our success.
The result is a new company with a significantly stronger balance sheet, a flexible capital structure, expected strong free cash flow potential, and new higher long-term growth targets. By any measure, this transaction has been a solid success, and we very much appreciate the work of all who had a hand in its realization.
A key element of our success has been our ability to secure the debt needed by new CCE going forward. Total gross debt is now approximately $2.4 billion with a weighted average interest rate of approximately 3%, and net debt of approximately $1.9 billion.
We also successfully completed the $10 per share cash distribution, returning approximately $3.4 billion to shareowners. As a result of the transaction new CCE has approximately 339 million common shares outstanding or approximately 347 million diluted common shares outstanding on a pro forma basis.
Recently, our Board authorized our inaugural quarterly dividend payable at $0.12 per common share, which is more than 30% above legacy CCE’s prior dividend level.
Looking ahead to 2011, we continue to expect to achieve our annualized dividend rate of $0.50 per share subject to Board approval. Now let’s look at our third quarter performance which as John mentioned produced excellent results.
Looking at our legacy European territories on a currency neutral basis third quarter revenues increased 4.5% and comparable operating income increased 7.5%. On a comparable and pro forma basis, including Norway and Sweden, we achieved earnings of $0.58 per diluted common share with pro forma net income up $202 million.
These comparable pro forma results include a negative currency impact of just over $0.05 per share for the quarter, and an estimated $0.08 negative impact for the first three quarters.
These results coupled with our outlook for the rest of the year have enabled us to establish new CCE’s pro forma full year guidance with comparable earnings per common share in a range of $1.74 to $1.78.
This earnings per share outlook includes an expected full year negative currency impact of approximately $0.09 per share based on year-to-date currency translation impact at actual rates and expected fourth quarter currency translation at recent rates.
Pro forma revenue is expected to be approximately $7.4 billion, with operating income slightly more than $900 million. Both on a comparable basis and including the expected currency translation impact.
Please note this outlook also includes expectations for recurring items, capital structure, tax rate, and results from Norway and Sweden, and importantly excludes non-recurring items as well as all North American results.
Going forward, we continue to expect long-term revenue growth of 4% to 6%, operating income growth of 6% to 8% with high single-digit earnings per share growth.
We expect these results to be driven by a balance of volume and pricing growth coupled with disciplined operational efficiencies and cost containment.
Share repurchase will be a factor in near term EPS growth, we expect the program will begin in this quarter, and we continue to expect to repurchase up to $1 billion of our shares over the next 18 months, based on current plans and subject to economic factors.
Looking ahead to 2011, though very early we believe we will likely exceed our long-term EPS target driven by the before mentioned share repurchase program. We will provide more details on our 2011 outlook in mid-December.
Overall, we are encouraged by the results we’ve accomplished and especially the quality of these results. We have great opportunities ahead of us with solid brands, vibrant markets, significant growth prospects, and world class strategies.
Again, thanks for joining us today, and now John, Hubert and I will be happy to open the line up for questions. Operator?

Frankly depending on the economy depending on the competitive environment, depending on whole host of things, which is why we no longer focus on any one of those items we focus on all three collectively in each year, each quarter even though you can assume we’ll be pulling the levers in the what we judge to be the optimum mix.
In terms of the operating income growth of 6 to 8 of course that’s based on revenue of 4 to 6 along with some efficiency ongoing efficiency improvements and it’s assuming that we have and I’d say just in general our whole business model is built on a modest growth rate for the NARTD category and a modest view around share gains that we will achieve year after year.
We believe we have the right brands, we have the right relationships with customers and we have the right people that collectively, we put all that together with our market place position, it is absolutely our intention and our plan and our assumption that we would have modest share growth on a consistent basis.
